text: <@UPX61UM51> I think that's potentially a really interesting way to approach it: "What a content marketer needs to know about (UX, CRO, Paid Ads, etc.)

There is a lot of content out there for content marketers (makes sense, right? :slightly_smiling_face: ) One gap I see is content about how to talk about your work in a business context, and how to bring larger teams with you on your work. You could have a whole section in here that's about "Reporting" or something like that and it 100% should not be about dashboards, but rather how to frame your work in relation to the business:
-- We got mentioned by this news outlet on this topic, here's why it matters
-- This key post is performing in this way, here is how that is going to help us achieve this larger business objective

I've worked with amazing CMs in my career, all of them have struggled to put together an EOM report that a CMO would read. And that's ok, but it's something we all need to get good at if we want to increase the impact we can have on the org.

user_profile.real_name: Janessa Lantz, VP of Marketing at dbt Labs
user_profile.name: janessalantz

text:
Agree with <@UJG12DM1V>. The two areas where I feel there's been the least written for content are:
1) How to sell your work to internal stakeholders (note: includes selling up to get resources and selling across so that people respect your time)
2) Management of a content team that's more than a few people

These are great suggestions, thank you both. right now, our teams are usually one [1] person and a part-time intern, but sometimes for big projects we'll either use freelances or another team's content marketer.

The element of getting buy-in would be especially important for clients.
